respondent.name: CITY OF PATERSON, NEW JERSEY, ET AL.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Case 14-1280, Heffernan v. City of Paterson, New Jersey. Mr. Frost.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: How would you define the right at issue in this case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: How would you define the right that your client wishes this Court to vindicate?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, that's just a restatement of -- of Elrod. I -- I -- would -- would -- would it be fair to the proposition that you are putting before the Court to say that you're asserting the right to be free from government inquiry into an oversight of your views? Would that be a fair statement?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Because -- look, do we -- it sounds to me from the way you began your argument that we take this case on the assumption that, if he had picked up the sign, that if he had been supporting the candidate for chief of police who was challenging the incumbent, if he had been engaged in the activity, that would be protected. He could not have been demoted. If -- you want us to take the case on that -- do we have to accept that proposition for you to prevail in this case?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but the -- the First Amendment talks about abridging freedom of speech, and I thought the case came to us on the proposition that he wasn't engaging in speech at all. That he was not engaging in association, he was not engaging in trying to convey a message, he was just picking up a sign for his mother. And if that's the basis on which the case comes to us, I'm not sure how he can say his freedom of speech has been abridged.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He wasn't associating with anybody any more -- any more than he was speaking. He was doing neither one.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He was associate -- associating with his mother, I suppose, in picking up the sign for her. But he was not expressing any political view. He was not associating with a political party. What case of ours vindicates the right Alderson Reporting Company that -- that Justice Kennedy described to you and which you readily agreed with? What -- what case of ours vindicates that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Elrod --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Elrod says you have a First Amendment right to favor a political party or not favor a political party, and you cannot be fired for doing so. That's not what happened here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Exactly. He was not expressing any First Amendment view whatever. I mean, he was fired for the wrong reason, but there's no constitutional right not to be fired for the wrong reason. If he was fired because his -- his -- his -- his government employer thought he had committed a felony and he hadn't, he might -- he might have a cause of action under some statute. But there -- there -- there's no constitutional right not to be fired for the wrong reason, and that's what happened here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Where do we say that? We never said that. Elrod and -- and Branti are -- are cases decided under the First Amendment. The First Amendment guarantees the right to freedom of speech and freedom of association. Your client was neither speaking nor associating. So how could he possibly have a cause of action under the First Amendment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: I don't understand -- I don't understand your answer. What -- what expressive activity did he engage in? He wasn't -- he was not allegedly demoted for failing to support the mayor. He was allegedly demoted for seemingly supporting the mayor's opponent.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, let me just -- to clarify what I -- how I thought the case was presented. Let's say the employer comes in to Smith and says, you know, Smith, I saw you getting a -- a -- a political sign, and you're -- and you're -- you're fired. And Smith says, it wasn't me. I was off, you know, in a different town then. In other words, it's a pure mistake of fact. Your answers, it seems to me, you try to get Alderson Reporting Company advantage of the fact that there -- you could perhaps have argued this was expressive activity. Say, oh, he was at a meeting, a political event. He was getting a sign. But your theory, I thought, didn't depend on that at all.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It was simply a mistake of fact. And then -- now, can the person who wasn't even there, can he bring a First Amendment challenge to his dismissal?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And then again -- but it's still not clear to me: What is the right that he's asserting? And -- and I'll back up while you're thinking about that. Is -- can a local government say that all our employees must be neutral in campaigns and must not take part in campaigns?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: They can vote, but they Alderson Reporting Company can't take part in campaigns? Like the Hatch Act?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Can the government insist on neutrality?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Is that an issue --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Is that an issue -- is that an issue in this case? Is there any allegation that there was such a policy of neutrality that no employee could engage in political activity?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry. I thought there was an unwritten policy.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Is there a remedy for your client, apart from this action under the First Amendment? Does he have civil service protections of any kind or -- or -- I don't know -- collective bargaining?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Let's just say: What would happen if the boss comes in and says, you know, for the -- you didn't turn off the lights last night. You're fired. Can he -- is there a way for him to say, I was on leave yesterday. It wasn't me.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, no. My point is that maybe this shouldn't be a constitutional violation Alderson Reporting Company if there are adequate remedies to address what may or may not be a First Amendment issue.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What -- what is the New Jersey Act? That's a strange act. It protects State employment only against First Amendment violations?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I can't imagine that. It must -- it must have other protections for State employee -- employees.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: How does it read? You have Alderson Reporting Company to violate the Federal constitution to get relief under New Jersey law?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yeah. That's what says. What is --  what does New Jersey law say?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What does the New Jersey law say? You brought it up. I didn't bring it up. What does it say?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So it says --  it says if you violate --  you can't fire a State employee in violation of the Federal constitution. That's what the New Jersey law says. What a strange law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You don't have the text of it, do you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The text of the New Jersey law, so we can know what we're talking about.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, Mr. Goldstein's brief says New Jersey law provides a statutory right of action for an attempt to violate an individual's civil rights. Is he wrong?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Yeah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: No. The question is not whether the New Jersey law somehow abrogates First Amendment rights. The question is whether he has a -- an independent remedy under State law. That's the question, I think, that's being asked.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: How could he? If we say there's no First Amendment right, what civil right has he --  was violated if --  if what Mr. Goldstein says is the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: --  is the state of the Alderson Reporting Company law attempting to violate civil rights? What right, if we say there isn't the First Amendment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, if we say it doesn't exist. You lose this case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Just that, the right you're claiming.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: He may have broader substantive rights under New Jersey law. I would be somewhat surprised if that were not the case. The civil rights to which this --  the New Jersey statute refers may refer to rights under the New Jersey constitution or other New Jersey laws.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Just --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: All of those things would be true if the mayor gave a speech saying I am going to fire anybody who's not a Republican. All of those things would be true. Would it chill people --  blah blah blah --  would there be a cause of action? Would anybody have a cause of action because of that speech?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yeah, just the speech. He hasn't fired anybody. He's just said I am going to fire anybody who's not a Republican, or anybody who's not a Republican will not get promoted.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Does anybody have a cause of action for that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Exactly. So --  so what counts is whether action was taken for a particular reason, not whether you chilled --  whether you chilled people, which you're arguing to us is this is unconstitutional because it chills other people. That --  that doesn't --  that just doesn't carry water.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Would you --  would you say that he was demoted because he gave the appearance of exercising his First Amendment rights?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You may.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Ms. Anders.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And what's your best case for that proposition?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And those cases, Ms. Anders -- I missed what you said those cases were. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You say in all of those cases, no First Amendment right was being exercised, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is that your point?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Was it clear that they hadn't?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Was it clear that they hadn't?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yeah. I thought in all of these cases up to now, whenever anybody's fired, demoted, or even not promoted, it hurts and -- and you want to bring a lawsuit sometimes. Up to now, those lawsuits would have to show I was asserting a First Amendment right, and it's for that reason that I was not promoted. But what you're saying is, you don't have to show that at all. All you have to assert is that the reason I was not promoted was that the -- the employer believed that I was thus and so or not thus and so. You don't have to show any assertion of a First Amendment right. You just show that the -- the employer liked Republicans, and that's enough.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: How do you know we haven't seen a flood of meritless lawsuits in that context?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yeah, the one that you were just referring to.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You're looking at the reported decisions rather than -- you haven't done any survey to see how many complaints have been filed in -- in this type of case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So are you saying there's a right to be secure from government oversight of your beliefs?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, that's a good idea, maybe. And maybe -- maybe it should be in some civil service act, but where do you find it in the First Amendment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is -- is that because you're concerned with a chill, or is there some other right that is -- is somehow affected that's a First Amendment right of the individual? You turn around and you say the government cannot act for an unconstitutional purpose, but we usually ask how is the defendant hurt? What is his right? That's still a little unclear to me.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I don't know why --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Please. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I don't know why the right isn't the right to be free from arbitrary employment action based on a mistake. That's his objection here. You made a mistake; you thought I was, you know, being politically active. I wasn't. I mean, isn't --  is there such a right under New Jersey law, you can't be fired for an arbitrary reason, or you can't be fired for a mistaken reason?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You've brought up in your Alderson Reporting Company brief, I think, that --  that the employer might have had a contract-type policy. I think you said we should remand to determine whether this employer said nobody engages in political activity.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Is it based on the facts up till now to think that there was such a policy?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Goldstein.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Can you explain, Mr. Goldstein, what sense it would make to say there are two people, the example Mr. Frost gave. One of them is a big supporter of Spagnola, and he gets demoted. And the other is politically neutral, and he gets demoted because the employer thinks he's a supporter of the rival mayoral candidate. What --  how could you make sense to a person of ordinary reason that one of them, the one who was in fact engaging in political activity, can't be demoted but the other one, who just was innocent, didn't do anything?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So just to make sure I understand what you're saying, suppose there's somebody who comes into office, and it's a Democrat. And he says I want as many Democrats as possible in my office, no matter what jobs they're doing. Now, what you're saying is he can't demote or fire Republicans. He can't remove, demote, or fire people who have other political views, neither Democrat or Republican. But what he can do is he can get rid of anybody who is just politically apathetic. Is that your view? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So you -- you encourage the person to be politically active and then fire him or her because they're politically active the wrong way? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Suppose the employee says, you know, I don't like the evening news. I -- I -- I like fiction. I -- I don't -- I don't know if I'm Republican or Democrat. I don't care.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: He -- he -- he cannot be fired? What is his right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: See, I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The --  the government has --  excuse me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The --  the --  the government has a right to compel him to declare one way or the other?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: See, I had always thought that the -- the idea behind those cases is a different one. That the idea has to do with why the government acted. And once we say that the government acted for an impermissible purpose, which is to -- let's say in my hypothetical, get as many Democrats as possible into the government, once we say that's an impermissible purpose, it matters not at all whether the person is a Republican, an -- an independent, or somebody who has never thought about politics in his life, because the government is acting in a way that's wrongful, irrespective of that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So does that mean that the government can compel speech of a person if the person really just doesn't care one way or the other?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Goldstein, let's take a Title VII case, and the employer fires a woman because he thinks she's pregnant. She brings a sex discrimination case and alleges, well, I wasn't pregnant. I just was gaining weight. So she has no sex discrimination claim, then, because she wasn't pregnant?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Those --  those statutes focus on the employer. The employer cannot discriminate on the basis -- Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- of sex.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And that employer was doing that. The First Amendment does not focus on the government; it focuses on the citizen. The citizen has a right to free speech and free association.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's the difference between the two cases.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What is --  what is the other law here? What --  what relief does he have?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, do -- do you agree that the Petitioner is entitled to relief under that provision of the collective bargaining agreement?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: In your hypothetical about stopping the person from crossing the street, or, they think, entering the parade, the individual is -- has no right to insist that the government doesn't make a First Amendment judgment about his activities?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: In -- in other words, the -- the -- the individual in the -- in -- in -- in -- the citizen of the United States, have no right, have -- have -- have no -- have no injury, have no interest in making sure the government doesn't evaluate everything they do from a political standpoint? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: We know that you can't -- let's assume in this particular position you can't be fired because you're a Republican or a Democrat and that's what they -- that's what -- what they do. But that -- the person did not engage in that activity. He's still -- he still is in the position of the government ascribing to him a political belief that he does not have.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Here, they thought and Alderson Reporting Company they acted.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It's not just something.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It's -- the government is taking action against a person because the government thinks that that person is exercising First Amendment rights.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And I thought -- and unlike Justice Scalia -- that the thrust of the First Amendment is operating on government. It says government, thou shalt not -- thou shalt not act on the basis of someone's expression, speech or belief.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes, so here, the government acted. No question they demoted the person. This was a detective, and they put him back on the beat. So the government acted. Why did they act? Because they thought that this person was engaging in political Alderson Reporting Company activity.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I guess I'm not sure how that works. It just seems to break down very easily, if you can't have a broad rule that says that you can fire everybody but Democrats. But you're saying that you are going to allow somebody to come in and fire people one at a time.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But you're saying -- and -- and I think you said this straight out -- you're saying I can come into an office -- I'm a Democrat. I can -- I can identify every person without a well-known political view, every couch potato out there, just fire one after another, after another, after another. Replace them all with Democrats, change the entire character of the office, do it for a reason that I prefer one political view to any other, and that that will not be a violation of the First Amendment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You want this Court to hold that the government of the United States has a right to ascribe to a citizen views that he or she does not hold.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: See, I had always thought that the First Amendment running through all our cases is an extremely strong strand. That part of the reason we have these protections is because we worry that government is doing things for impermissible reasons. That the government wants to create a world of speech in which everybody agrees with it and nobody opposes it. And that's a fundamental tenet of what the First Amendment and all our cases are about. And you're saying, oh, no. The government's motive doesn't really matter as long as you can't point to somebody who is holding up a sign.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Can I just approach the same thing from a different perspective? Suppose can Congress pass a law or a legislature pass a law that attempts to abridge the freedom of speech. Is that a violation of the First Amendment? It's an attempt.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, let's say there doesn't have to be a thousand examples.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You say that's the law. No one can espouse in a public place the political philosophy of Ruritanianism, okay?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay. I mean, I doubt that they'll pass such a law -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- but I just -- substitute any one that you want for that. They pass it. And by the way, the six people who hold that philosophy all leave on a boat before the effective date, but -- or what's more likely, they bring a declaratory judgment action, and the law never takes effect. And therefore, it had no impact. And that happens every day of the week. I'm just wondering if such a law, which is an attempt -- it's right on the books as blatant as you Alderson Reporting Company want -- whether that violates the First Amendment. That's a serious question. I'm not taking a point of view. I want to know what you think.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, I just want to know, is it yes or no? Does it -- in your opinion, does it attempt to -- a clear attempt to violate the First Amendment in a statute? It has general application. Does it violate the First Amendment? Does it abridge the freedom of speech?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It is unconstitutional.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It will have a lot of bad effects. It will have all kinds of chilling effects all over the place.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no, by chance it happens not to succeed. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's my hypothetical. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Of course. And I'm just asking you if, in fact, they think it will succeed, they want it to succeed, that's why they passed it, and through a fluke it fails, does the fact that it fails mean that it doesn't violate, it doesn't --  does it not --  does it or does it not violate the First Amendment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It does not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And he fails --  if it fails --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Or -- or you could say that the law is passed by Congress but vetoed by the President, is there a violation of the Constitution?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: We're off on a tangent because there's no injury in this situation when the law doesn't go into effect. But coming back to what Justice Breyer, I believe, is attempting to say -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I don't know, Mr. Goldstein, that I understand either. And I think Justice Kagan asked you this. Why does it matter -- and we don't care whether someone is a Republican or not in Elrod and Branti and those cases -- and you say it's only because it's a policy. The intent of the government is to say I'm not going to promote anybody who is not a Democrat or not a Republican. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, someone, they have come along and not promoted people.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right? So you have to have someone come in and say I'm not a Democrat?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm not a --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: --  Republican? Or you need someone to tell you what they are?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So why isn't it simple to say, I'm not hiring you, or, I'm demoting you because you politically associated? And doesn't that chill the person from even walking by a campaign? Doesn't it chill others who do want to associate marginally?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm assuming there's no policy in place, or that there's not --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: There's nothing to prevent this otherwise, like the Hatch Act.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It --  it is bizarre. And do --  do you really believe, Mr. Goldstein, that the Constitution does not solve all problems? You --  you -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: --  made a statement to that effect. You really believe that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It doesn't solve every problem. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But that is a First Amendment problem for the reason that lots of other people will have their speech chilled. And normally in the law there is a doctrine where the person who does Alderson Reporting Company the bad thing makes a mistake, he's held anyway. That's true of transferred intent. You shoot A, but you meant to shoot B. It's true of --  of attempts generally.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That is to say I would think that a statute that has a chilling effect on the speech of millions of people but is directly aimed at A, B, and C, if because of some fluke A, B, and C are not themselves injured, nonetheless everybody else is, and it would violent the First Amendment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That, I think, is what you have here, which is why I raised my point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you know of any case in which we have relied on chilling effects where what was at issue was a one-off like this one as opposed to a -- a general policy which had a chilling effect? I don't know of any case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And the -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And the question in this case seems to me to be highly artificial. It's sort of --  it's like a law school hypothetical.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: How often will it be the case that an employee will be unable to allege any expression or any association that is protected by the --  the First Amendment? It seems to me quite rare. And it may be that this case comes to us the way it does because the plaintiff was dealing with two things, one was the First Amendment, and the other --  I mean one was the issue that's --  the question of his motivation, and the other was this alleged policy prohibiting any kind of political activity. Even in the --  the person who is just apathetic, is there not a --  a First Amendment right to be --  say, I don't --  I don't like politics, I don't want anything to do with politics, I'm not going to register, I'm not going to vote?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry. You have to -- you have to show some facts to draw that inference.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I mean, you just can't say, I'm involved in this and the employer fired me because of that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: To show some connection between the firing and --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- the political belief.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Goldstein, I mean, if somebody had come in to me before today's argument and just said, does the First Amendment prevent the government from punishing a person because that person does not share the government's views, I would have said, why, yes, of course the First Amendment protects that. That's the whole point of the First Amendment. And now you're telling me, no, the First Amendment does not prevent the government from punishing a person because that person doesn't share the government's views, unless that person is actively opposed to the government's views. But if that person just really could not Alderson Reporting Company care less, which a lot of people in this country could not care less; they don't vote, they don't pay attention, they wouldn't know who was running. But the government can punish that person because that person doesn't share the government's views. And I would have said, that is one strange doctrine.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Frost, you have a minute left.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm -- I'm so totally confused. I know it's the way it was presented to us, but I thought he testified that he had made a choice not to get involved in the campaign but that Spagnola was his friend and he supported him. So he wasn't neutral; he just wasn't engaging in associational conduct by choice. That's what I thought.
